title: The Dow Is Jumping Because the U.S. and China Finally Agreed to Talk Trade Again
text:
Text size

8:29 a.m. The Dow Jones Industrial Average looks set for a much higher open after the U.S. and China agreed to hold talks in October.

Dow futures have gained 235 points, or 0.9%, while S&P 500 futures have risen 0.8%, and Nasdaq Composite futures have climbed 1.1%.

Reports emerged overnight that the U.S. and China had agreed to talk, and that was enough to send the market higher. If the gains hold through the open, the range that had been in place since early August would break to the upside. But can already observers are finding reasons to doubt the rise. “US stocks are poised for a strong open after the world’s two largest economies signaled trade negotiations are set to continue at the highest levels in October, while lower level meetings will take place this month,” writes Oanda’s Edward Moya. “The US is set to turn up the tariff pressure again on October 1st and if we don’t see that threat taken off, markets will be skeptical that the October meeting likely not see anything meaningful happen.”

This is meaningful, however, at least for today. While the stock market is moving higher, bonds prices are getting knocked lower, which means yields are rising. The 10-year Treasury yield has gained 0.066 percentage point to 1.53%, and the 30-year is back over 2%. Even better, one part of the yield curve is no longer inverted, as the difference between the 10-year and 2-year yields is solidly positive for a second day in a row.

Is it time for stocks to follow the curve higher?

Write to Ben Levisohn at Ben.Levisohn@barrons.com
description: Reports emerged overnight that the U.S. and China had agreed to talk, and that was enough to send the market higher. If the gains hold through the open, the range that had been in place since early August would break to the upside.
